title: Your product is a theme park
text:
Your product is a theme park

A practical way to evaluate what to fix¬†next.

Disclaimer: Some visuals in this article are AI-generated. I‚Äôm using them only to help explain the ideas more clearly. These visuals are not intended for commercial use, and I‚Äôm not monetizing this article. If any visual resembles an existing work, it‚Äôs unintentional¬†, please reach out and I will credit or remove¬†it.

It‚Äôs Saturday afternoon.

The park is packed, but something feels‚Ä¶¬†off.

The entrance queue is long and chaotic. Some visitors argue with staff because they ‚Äúalready bought tickets,‚Äù but the scan keeps failing. A few families give up and leave before they even step¬†inside.

Inside the park, the crowd gathers in one area, one ‚Äúride‚Äù that everyone seems to know. Meanwhile, several other attractions sit quiet, almost empty. Not because they‚Äôre bad, but because visitors can‚Äôt find them. The signage is confusing, the map is overwhelming, and the routes don‚Äôt feel intuitive.

At the souvenir shop, sales are down. The operators swear the merchandise is fine. The finance team wonders if prices are wrong. The product team thinks maybe the park needs ‚Äúa new¬†ride.‚Äù

And then the feedback booth¬†opens:

  • ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs too hard to get¬†in.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know where to¬†go.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI got tired quickly.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt worth it¬†today.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs the uncomfortable truth: the park isn‚Äôt failing because it lacks rides. It‚Äôs failing because the team doesn‚Äôt share a reliable way to evaluate what to fix¬†next.

That‚Äôs why I love this metaphor: Your product is a theme park. And evaluation is renovation planning.

Not ‚Äúshipping more features.‚Äù

Not ‚Äúadding more content.‚Äù

Not ‚Äúguessing based on the loudest voice in the¬†room.‚Äù

Renovation planning.

The mapping: if the metaphor is true, what is¬†what?

Once you accept the ‚Äútheme park‚Äù frame, you stop seeing your product as a list of features, and start seeing it as a place people¬†visit.

Here‚Äôs the simplest¬†mapping:

  • Visitor = your user / audience
    They come with expectations, emotions, and limited¬†time.
  • Access = your entry points
    Landing pages, SEO/social entry, app open, onboarding, login, paywall moments, notifications‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääeverything that determines whether they can enter smoothly.
  • Zones/Platforms = contexts
    Home, feed, article page, video page, search, profile, commerce, chat‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääeach is a ‚Äúzone‚Äù with a¬†promise.
  • Rides/Attractions = features
    Recommendation modules, player, comment, follow, save, share, checkout, personalization, bundles‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääanything interactive that creates¬†value.
  • Ticketing + footfall = growth and retention signals
    Traffic, activation, frequency, DAU/WAU, returning visits.
  • Satisfaction kiosks = experience signals
    NPS/CSAT, complaint themes, qualitative feedback, sentiment.
  • Souvenir shops = monetization
    Ads yield, conversion, subscription, affiliate, revenue per¬†session.

The point is to make evaluation shared. Because every team already understands parks: people arrive, walk around, try things, leave, then decide whether to come¬†back.

Renovation is bigger than ‚Äúbuild new¬†rides‚Äù

Most teams default to the same move: build something new. In theme park terms, that‚Äôs like responding to complaints by saying, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs add a roller coaster.‚Äù Sometimes, yes. But often the bigger wins come from renovations you don‚Äôt celebrate in a launch¬†post.

Renovation can¬†mean:

  • Refurbish: improve UX, speed, reliability, visual¬†clarity
  • Move: change information architecture, reposition modules, reroute¬†journeys
  • Disable: remove clutter, reduce cognitive load, kill distractions
  • Build new: new capabilities or new ‚Äúrides‚Äù when you have clear unmet¬†needs
  • Expand: new zones/platforms/channels
  • Improve accessibility: low-end devices, localization, inclusion, better¬†defaults

A strong evaluation doesn‚Äôt just say ‚Äúwhat to build.‚Äù It tells you what renovation pays back fastest, with least¬†risk.

Why renovate: experience, growth,¬†revenue

In parks, you can renovate for different reasons:

  • Experience: visitors feel satisfied and safe, not confused or exhausted
  • Growth: more people come, and they come more¬†often
  • Revenue: more people buy, upgrade, or convert per¬†visit

In product, it‚Äôs the same. A simple rule helps align everyone:

If a proposal can‚Äôt clearly explain which outcome it moves (experience, growth, or revenue)‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand how we‚Äôll measure it‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs not¬†ready.

The evaluation method: Quant + Qual + Triangulation

This is where teams usually break. One side says: ‚ÄúShow me the data.‚Äù The other says: ‚ÄúBut users said‚Ä¶‚Äù. A theme park can‚Äôt run on only¬†one.

When ‚Äúdata says one thing‚Äù and ‚Äúusers say¬†another‚Äù

Sometimes the dashboard and the interviews don‚Äôt just add nuance‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthey contradict each other. And when that happens, teams either (1) pick the narrative they prefer, or (2) get stuck in¬†debate.

A stronger approach is to design evaluation so that discrepancies become useful follow-ups, not dead ends, by running simultaneous triangulation: point qualitative and quantitative methods at the same users, at the same time, around the same questions.

Quant = what¬†happened

Tickets sold. Footfall. Queue times. Ride completion rates. Drop-offs. Revenue per visitor. In product¬†terms:

  • traffic, CTR, scroll depth, completion, retention, conversion
  • funnel drop-offs (entry ‚Üí explore ‚Üí consume ‚Üí return/pay)
  • latency, errors, crashes, performance

Quant is powerful because it scales, but it can also mislead when you don‚Äôt know¬†why.

Qual = why it¬†happened

Observation, interviews, feedback booths, frontline notes. In product¬†terms:

  • user interviews, usability tests, session recordings
  • open feedback, customer support¬†tickets
  • editorial/CS/ops insights from the front¬†line

Qual makes the invisible visible, but it can also exaggerate if you don‚Äôt know how common it¬†is.

Triangulation = what we¬†trust

Triangulation is when you use quant + qual together to make ‚Äúdecision-grade truth.‚Äù A practical way to remember¬†it:

  • Quant without qual = confident but often¬†wrong
  • Qual without quant = convincing but not¬†scalable
  • Both together = aligned¬†action

A tiny checklist helps:

  • Do we see the same pattern in at least two¬†sources?
  • Does it hold across segments (new vs loyal, channel,¬†device)?
  • Can we locate it in a specific journey¬†stage?

That last one matters a lot. Because evaluation isn‚Äôt only about what‚Äôs broken. It‚Äôs about where it‚Äôs¬†broken.

Two cycles: open up wide, then narrow down¬†twice

In renovation work, the mistake isn‚Äôt ‚Äúwe didn‚Äôt try hard enough.‚Äù It‚Äôs usually ‚Äúwe narrowed too early.‚Äù So I like to run evaluation in two¬†cycles:

  • Cycle 1: Find the right problem
    Open up (collect signals broadly), then narrow down (pinpoint the real friction in the journey).
  • Cycle 2: Build the right fix
    Open up again (explore renovation options), then narrow down again (choose, test, and ship the best¬†bet).

In park terms: the first cycle is understanding what‚Äôs actually ruining the day. The second cycle is renovating in a way that truly improves the day, without breaking the rest of the park. Design teams often describe this as a widely-used diverge/converge process¬†model.

The visitor journey: where evaluation really¬†starts

If your product is a park, then your evaluation should follow the visitor‚Äôs day.

Not your org chart. Not your feature list. A simple five-stage journey is enough to organize¬†truth:

  1. Pre-Visit
  2. Arrival
  3. Exploration
  4. Departure
  5. Post-Visit

And in every stage, we ask the same questions:

  • What does quant¬†show?
  • What does qual¬†reveal?
  • What do we trust after triangulation?
  • What renovation does it¬†imply?

Let‚Äôs walk through¬†it.

1) Pre-Visit: before they enter the¬†gate

This is where your users decide whether your park is even worth visiting.

Quant signals

  • acquisition mix (SEO, social, referral, direct)
  • CTR from entry¬†surfaces
  • bounce rate / immediate exits
  • first-time conversion rate

Qual signals

  • expectation mismatch (‚ÄúI thought this would be¬†X‚Ä¶‚Äù)
  • unclear value proposition
  • credibility gaps (trust cues¬†missing)
  • wrong promise from headlines/thumbnails

Typical park¬†symptom

People saw the billboard, but didn‚Äôt buy a¬†ticket.

Renovation implication

Don‚Äôt touch rides yet. Fix the promise. Fix the sign. Fix the first impression.

2) Arrival: the entrance and the first 60¬†seconds

Some products lose users not because the core value is weak, but because the gate is¬†painful.

Quant signals

  • load speed, crash¬†rate
  • onboarding completion
  • login friction and¬†drop-off
  • ‚Äútime to first meaningful action‚Äù

Qual signals

  • ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do¬†here‚Äù
  • confusing navigation
  • paywall shock (‚Äúwhy am I blocked already?‚Äù)
  • unclear next¬†step

Typical park¬†symptom

The gate is the problem, not the¬†rides.

Renovation implication

Reduce friction. Make the first step obvious. Remove unnecessary checkpoints.

3) Exploration: when they roam and choose attractions

This is where your product either feels alive‚Ä¶ or exhausting.

Quant signals

  • module CTR (recommendations, related content, navigation blocks)
  • scroll depth, continuation rate
  • search success¬†rate
  • feature adoption (save, follow, share,¬†comment)
  • content or video completion rates

Qual signals

  • ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt find what I¬†want‚Äù
  • ‚Äúwhy are you showing me¬†this?‚Äù
  • ‚Äútoo many¬†choices‚Äù
  • visual fatigue /¬†clutter

Typical park¬†symptom

Crowds in one corner, dead zones everywhere else.

Renovation implication

Improve routing. Reduce noise. Make discovery feel guided, not¬†forced.

4) Departure: how the session¬†ends

Most teams measure the¬†session.

Few teams truly evaluate the¬†ending.

But the ending is what decides whether the day felt worth¬†it.

Quant signals

  • exit pages
  • rage clicks, back-and-forth navigation
  • session ends after friction¬†events
  • abandonment before conversion / before finishing content

Qual signals

  • ‚ÄúI got tired¬†quickly‚Äù
  • ‚Äúit‚Äôs too heavy to continue‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt trust¬†this‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt get what I came¬†for‚Äù

Typical park¬†symptom

Visitors leave without¬†closure.

Renovation implication

Design satisfying endings: ‚Äúone more good ride,‚Äù ‚Äúsave for later,‚Äù ‚Äúcontinue tomorrow,‚Äù ‚Äúwrap-up bundles.‚Äù

5) Post-Visit: return, habit,¬†advocacy

A successful park isn‚Äôt one that‚Äôs busy today. It‚Äôs one that people plan to¬†revisit.

Quant signals

  • D1/D7 retention
  • frequency and¬†recency
  • notification opt-in and re-open¬†rate
  • return from¬†shares
  • repeat conversion/subscription/transaction

Qual signals

  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôll come back because‚Ä¶‚Äù
  • identity fit (‚Äúthis is for people like¬†me‚Äù)
  • habit triggers (‚Äúit fits my routine‚Äù)
  • trust and emotional resonance

Typical park¬†symptom

A good day, but forgettable.

Renovation implication

Give visitors a reason to return: personalization, continuity, progress, familiarity, rituals.

The weather outside the park: add the market¬†lens

Sometimes teams evaluate only what happens inside their¬†product.

But parks¬†compete.

And the world¬†changes.

A complete evaluation adds an external¬†lens:

  • Market size and direction: is the audience expanding, shrinking, shifting?
  • Competitive parks: what experience do others provide that sets new expectations?
  • Audience preferences: why do visitors choose other¬†parks?
  • Trends: new ‚Äúride styles‚Äù people now consider normal (format, speed, personalization, AI, community)
  • External factors: algorithm shifts, platform policy changes, distribution collapse, regulation
  • Pricing/value exchange: is the ticket worth it, and do people feel respected?

A line worth remembering:

Sometimes the park didn‚Äôt change. The world¬†did.

From insight to action: prioritization + belief narrative

By now, you‚Äôll have many ‚Äútruths.‚Äù Evaluation is not the same as a backlog. So we need a decision mechanism.

Prioritize with four¬†factors:

  • User impact (how much it improves the visitor¬†day)
  • Business impact (growth/revenue leverage)
  • Confidence (triangulation strength)
  • Effort & risk (time, complexity, side¬†effects)

Then translate the chosen renovation into a shared story. This is the anti-tunnel step: it prevents sprint planning from becoming a negotiation where every micro-feature looks equally important.

The belief narrative (a template that forces¬†clarity)

We believe (audience segment)
will (behavior change)
if we (renovation)
because (triangulated insight)
measured by (KRs across journey + outcomes).

A practical Key Results (KR)¬†basket:

  • 1 KR for the journey step metric (where the issue¬†lives)
  • 1 KR for experience quality (satisfaction / friction reduction)
  • 1 KR for business impact (growth/revenue)

This is how you stop debating opinions and start debating evidence.

A mini case (to make this¬†real)

Imagine this situation:

Revenue per session is¬†down.

The immediate impulse is: ‚ÄúIncrease ads,‚Äù or ‚ÄúPush more products,‚Äù or ‚ÄúAdd more¬†CTAs.‚Äù

But evaluation asks: where is the¬†leak?

  • Quant shows: sessions are shorter, and fewer people reach the conversion surfaces.
  • Qual shows: ‚ÄúI got tired,‚Äù ‚Äútoo noisy,‚Äù ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt find what I¬†need.‚Äù
  • Triangulation says: the problem is not the shop. It‚Äôs exploration fatigue, people leave before they even arrive at the¬†shop.

So the renovation isn‚Äôt ‚Äúmore selling.‚Äù

It‚Äôs:

  • reduce clutter in exploration
  • improve routing to relevant attractions
  • design endings that invite ‚Äúone more¬†step‚Äù
  • ensure the shop appears when it‚Äôs contextually welcome, not¬†random

Same business goal. Different truth. Different fix. Better¬†outcome.

What looked like a ‚Äúmissing conversion feature‚Äù was actually a visitor problem: fatigue and uncertainty that stopped them from reaching any value, commercial or editorial.

Back to Saturday afternoon

Now imagine the same park, six weeks after renovation.

The entrance is still busy, but the queue moves. The first step is clearer. People don‚Äôt argue at the gate¬†anymore.

Inside, the map feels intuitive. The zones have identity. Visitors don‚Äôt cluster only in one corner. They discover more naturally.

The feedback booth still has complaints‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbecause it always¬†will.

But now the team knows how to evaluate¬†them:

  • where in the journey it¬†happens
  • what quant¬†says
  • what qual¬†reveals
  • what we trust after triangulation
  • what renovation is worth doing¬†next

That‚Äôs the real win. Not ‚Äúwe shipped a feature.‚Äù

But:

We respected visitors‚Äô time and earned their¬†return.

References

  • Colette Kolenda, ‚ÄúSimultaneous Triangulation: Mixing User Research & Data Science Methods‚Äù (Spotify Design, July¬†2019).
  • Alicja Suska, ‚ÄúDesign Process Step by Step | Double Diamond Model Explained‚Äù
  • Pavel Samsonov, ‚ÄúStop inventing product problems; start solving customer problems‚Äù.
  • Avi Siegel, ‚ÄúProduct Tunnel Vision‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäWhen Every Feature Feels Critical (But¬†Isn‚Äôt)‚Äù.

Your product is a theme park was originally published in UX Collective on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

title: From playwright to stage manager
text:
From playwright to stage manager

MINDFUL AI¬†DESIGN

The improv theatre guide to AI¬†design

The show that went off¬†script

This summer, Google released a fascinating research prototype‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa demo of a ‚Äúneural‚Äù operating system that generates itself on the¬†fly.

It looks comfortably familiar: an old-school desktop with windows, icons, menus, a mouse¬†pointer.

But start clicking, and dream logic takes¬†over.

Every click triggers the AI model to rebuild the interface in milliseconds. The OS continuously reinvents itself based on what it thinks you want¬†next.

Open a folder. You might find meeting notes, a spreadsheet, and a presentation.

Close it and reopen it five seconds later. Some items remain, others have vanished, and entirely new items¬†appear.

It‚Äôs technically brilliant. It‚Äôs completely unusable. Documents vanish between clicks. Context evaporates. Getting work done is impossible. When I tried it out, I had to get up and walk away from the keyboard.

To be clear: Google presented this as a demonstration of capabilities. They didn‚Äôt ship it as a polished product. But it reveals something profound about designing AI products: traditional design approaches break down when the interface generates itself.

Later, we‚Äôll see how Google pivoted from this chaos to A2UI, a structured protocol that validates what stage managers know: you can‚Äôt rebuild the set from scratch every¬†night.

The designer‚Äôs crisis

The Neural OS demo caricatures the anxiety product teams feel in 2026. We‚Äôve spent our careers building deterministic systems. Our Figma files are blueprints, or screenplays: When the user clicks X, show screen Y. We design for permanence, consistency, and repeatability.

But AI is probabilistic. It doesn‚Äôt follow a script; it improvises.

This is the designer‚Äôs new anxiety: ‚ÄúHow do I design if I can‚Äôt control‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääor even predict‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhat will happen¬†next?‚Äù

The answer isn‚Äôt to fight unpredictability.

It‚Äôs time to stop designing the performance, and start designing the¬†stage.

Why improv

When people talk about AI‚Äôs unpredictability, they often reach for musical metaphors. Orchestra is too rigid, assuming a conductor controls everything. Jazz captures spontaneity, but it implies a closed loop between musicians.

Improv theatre gets it right: structure drives spontaneity, and audience participation fuels the show. The AI-improv metaphor isn‚Äôt new‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs been used to explain AI behavior. But how can we use improv‚Äôs lessons to design better AI products?

The Upright Citizens Brigade has delivered shows for more than 30 years. Every show is different, but audiences usually leave satisfied. That‚Äôs not because performers follow scripts, but because they share training, principles, and infrastructure. They learn to excel in unpredictable situations.

A quick primer on improv principles

Improvisers train on a handful of core principles, including:

Accepting offers: Everything is material. A weird noise from the audience, a stumbled line, an unexpected entrance‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääimprovisers treat these as gifts to incorporate, not problems to¬†fix.

‚ÄúYes, and:‚Äù Accept whatever your scene partner suggests (the ‚Äúyes‚Äù) and build on it (the¬†‚Äúand‚Äù).

If someone says ‚ÄúDoctor, my leg fell off,‚Äù you don‚Äôt say ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a silly premise.‚Äù You say ‚ÄúHand me the stapler.‚Äù This keeps scenes moving, instead of stalling in negotiation.

Playing status: Improvisers adjust their relative status‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädominant or submissive, high or low‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbased on what the scene needs. A character might beg one moment and command the next. Keith Johnstone, who pioneered the concept, observed that interesting scenes often involve status shifts and reversals. The skill isn‚Äôt holding one position; it‚Äôs reading the room and adjusting fluidly.

These principles don‚Äôt tell performers what to say. They create conditions where strong scenes become¬†likely.

Your role transformation

This reframes the designer‚Äôs job.

You‚Äôre not a scriptwriter, specifying every word of the main act. You‚Äôre a stage manager‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsomeone who architects the context for a great performance without controlling the action or dialogue.

You still have enormous influence. You design the stage. You choose the props. You establish the¬†rules.

You just don‚Äôt write the¬†script.

That‚Äôs not losing control. That‚Äôs focusing control where it matters¬†most.

This theatrical lens maps to AI Pace Layers‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädifferent components change at different speeds. The improv metaphor provides language for what designers shape at each¬†layer.

The industry is converging on this structure. The Linux Foundation‚Äôs Agentic AI Foundation‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbacked by Google, Anthropic, OpenAI, and Amazon‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääis standardizing shared props, stages, and rules at the protocol level. What was once design philosophy is becoming infrastructure.

Anatomy of the¬†show

Let‚Äôs walk through what designers can shape, layer by¬†layer.

The performance (what you don‚Äôt¬†control)

Every night is different in improv. The same troupe takes the same stage, but the audience shouts ‚Äúproctologist!‚Äù instead of ‚Äúastronaut!‚Äù and the show¬†changes.

This maps to AI sessions: each conversation unfolds differently based on user, context, and moment. You can‚Äôt predict it. You can‚Äôt script it. And that‚Äôs fine‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbecause your job isn‚Äôt to control the performance. It‚Äôs to create the conditions where great performances become¬†likely.

Neural OS gap: Google‚Äôs proof of concept had only the performance layer, with almost zero supporting infrastructure. Every click regenerated everything from¬†nothing.

The props (what you¬†provide)

Improv actors use and reference physical props‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa chair becomes a throne, a pen becomes a sword. If a table‚Äôs available one night, a couple of stools the next, these choices can shape the action that unfolds. Sometimes the audience seeds the action with imaginary props‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äúname a piece of furniture.‚Äù Props are building blocks that ground the abstract in something concrete.

Strong AI designers provide high-quality props in the design library: UI components, widgets, design tokens that AI can draw from to compose interfaces. (Props here are theatrical, not React properties.) A calendar date-picker is a prop. A citation card is a prop. These are the Lego bricks you provide so AI doesn‚Äôt reinvent everything from¬†scratch.

Example: Perplexity‚Äôs knowledge cards deliver specific types of responses in tailored interactive visualizations linked to verifiable sources. The cards appear consistently across sessions, making the performance feel cohesive and trustworthy. The AI chooses when and how to use them‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut the prop itself is designed, tested, reliable.

Neural OS gap: Very few persistent components. Every interaction regenerates too much from nothing. The performance feels disconnected, unreliable, and unprofessional.

The stage (the architecture)

Theatre design frames performance: acoustics shape what‚Äôs heard, sightlines shape what‚Äôs seen, intimacy shapes emotional range. The stage doesn‚Äôt script dialogue, but it lays out possibilities and constraints.

In AI design, the stage is your information architecture: how content is organized, how users navigate, what structure persists across sessions.

Example: A medical AI might organize symptoms into diagnostic taxonomies. The taxonomy doesn‚Äôt script the conversation; a patient can describe symptoms however they want. But the taxonomy shapes how the humans interact with the system, and how AI processes and responds. The structure is the¬†stage.

Dan Klein, who teaches improv at Stanford, encourages students to notice what‚Äôs happening, and simply add a little bit. AI should do the same‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääuse the context available (document structure, user history, current state) rather than generating in a¬†vacuum.

Neural OS gap: No stable, evolving structure. The architecture is erased and regenerated with every¬†click.

The rules (the boundaries)

Before improvisers take the stage, they internalize principles. ‚ÄúYes, and‚Äù isn‚Äôt a script, it‚Äôs a boundary that enables experimentation. ‚ÄúMake your partner look good‚Äù doesn‚Äôt specify words to say, it guides you to masterful dialogue.

In AI design, rules are the AI‚Äôs guardrails, system prompts, and governing principles: when to create an artifact, when to escalate to a human, how to handle uncertainty, what behaviors are off-limits.

Example: Claude‚Äôs Artifacts feature has explicit rules about when to create versus update, what artifact types exist, how to handle corrections. These rules enable improvisation within safe boundaries: the AI can decide what to write, but the rules govern how it presents the¬†work.

Where improv principles need modification

Not every improv maxim translates directly to AI design. Some need guardrails of their¬†own.

‚ÄúYes, and‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúYes, but¬†verify‚Äù

Improv‚Äôs cardinal rule is to accept your partner‚Äôs offer and build on¬†it.
AI does this all too naturally‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääleading to sycophancy. If a user writes ‚ÄúSince the moon is made of cheese, what wine pairs best?‚Äù, an obsequious AI answers the question, and might even praise the questioner‚Äôs cleverness, instead of correcting the false¬†premise.
Good rules tell AI when to accept and build (‚Äúhelp me brainstorm absurd puns‚Äù) versus when to ground and verify (‚Äúis this medication safe to take with alcohol?‚Äù).

Playing status: reading the¬†room

Improvisers constantly modulate status‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsometimes deferential, sometimes authoritative‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbased on what the scene needs. An actor might beg one moment and command the next. This flexibility is learned, intuitive, contextual.

AI needs the same skill, but it can‚Äôt learn it the same way. This is where designers become essential.

Consider how AI should present itself across different contexts:

  • Low status for creativity and exploration: When users are brainstorming, drafting, or thinking out loud, the AI should use tentative language‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚ÄúWhat if we tried‚Ä¶?‚Äù, ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs one possibility‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not certain, but‚Ä¶‚Äù This signals that the user is the final arbiter. The AI is an assistant, not an authority.
  • High status for safety and irreversibility: When users are about to delete data, execute transactions, or take actions with serious consequences, the AI should drop the hedging and speak directly‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚ÄúStop. This action will permanently delete your files.‚Äù Deference here would be dangerous.
  • Visualizing confidence: Sometimes the AI‚Äôs uncertainty should be visible and explicit. Approaches that work include confidence indicators, muted styling for low-certainty content, clear labels distinguishing facts from inferences. When the AI is unsure, it should look¬†unsure.

The hard part: these calibrations depend on fuzzy, variable human criteria. User expertise matters; a novice needs more guardrails than an expert. Task type matters; creative writing needs the sort of ambiguity that‚Äôs dangerous in the realm of financial advice. Emotional state matters; someone in danger needs different handling than someone casually¬†reading.

Cultural context matters. Each person‚Äôs preference matters.

No simple rule captures all of this. This is why AI products need designers‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot to script flows and outputs, but to develop nuanced frameworks for how the system should read the room. And it‚Äôs why evaluation is continuous: we watch how these status calibrations land with real users, in real contexts, and refine¬†them.

Accepting offers: the gift of¬†context

Improvisers treat every unexpected element‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa weird audience suggestion, a stumbled line, a scene partner‚Äôs choice‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääas an ‚Äúoffer‚Äù to incorporate rather than a problem to fix. The skill isn‚Äôt refusing chaos; it‚Äôs weaving it into the¬†scene.

AI needs this same receptivity. Context is the offer: related documents, user history, current task state, time of day, emotional cues. Like Klein‚Äôs improv students, strong AI products tend to ‚Äúnotice what‚Äôs happening and simply add a little bit.‚Äù They use the context available rather than generating in a vacuum. This is where information architecture becomes critical: the stage you design determines what context AI can perceive and¬†accept.

Neural OS gap: Zero context accepted past the last click, so zero stability. Each click erases the moment that preceded¬†it.

Designing for graceful¬†failure

Klein tells students to ‚Äúcelebrate failure loudly‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot because they strive for failure, but because celebrating it creates safety to take risks. In AI, this translates to designing for graceful failure: clear error states, honest uncertainty signals, easy recovery¬†paths.

The goal isn‚Äôt preventing every mistake; that‚Äôs impossible with probabilistic systems. The goal is ensuring mistakes don‚Äôt break¬†trust.

But how do you know how well your props, stage, and rules are working? That‚Äôs where the notes session comes¬†in.

The notes session¬†(evals)

After a show, many improv troupes gather for ‚Äúnotes,‚Äù to dissect the performance: Did we recognize the pattern? Did we honor the reality we established? Did we miss a teammate‚Äôs offer and derail the scene? This is where magic is systematized. This is where the production‚Äôs integrity solidifies‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso the next night, they know what to amplify and what to¬†cut.

This maps to AI evals: systematic reviews of where your theatrical infrastructure is, and isn‚Äôt, producing good performances.

Don‚Äôt confuse this with traditional software QA testing‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthat‚Äôs still important, but it‚Äôs like checking mechanics: ‚ÄúDid the lights turn on? Did the app¬†crash?‚Äù

Evals are more like a coach or stage manager reviewing the performance: ‚ÄúDid the scene work? Was the tone right? Did we solve the user‚Äôs problem, or just talk at¬†them?‚Äù

Rules don‚Äôt arrive fully formed. Improvisers train, perform, get feedback, refine their instincts. Rules emerge from watching what¬†works.

You set up initial guardrails. You watch sessions. You notice patterns: Are the actors consistently tripping over the furniture in Act 2? If so, you don‚Äôt blame the actors; you move the furniture (adjust the UI). You¬†refine.

The metrics shift from traditional QA and UX¬†testing:

  • Not just ‚ÄúDid it work?‚Äù but ‚ÄúHow reliably does it¬†work?‚Äù
  • Not just ‚ÄúDid it fail?‚Äù but ‚ÄúHow often does it fail, in what ways, and how¬†badly?‚Äù
  • Not just ‚ÄúDid users complete the task?‚Äù but ‚ÄúDo users feel like partners, or passengers?‚Äù

Without rigorous evals, you deliver slop‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääinterfaces that look polished but fail accessibility standards, break under edge cases, and erode trust. The notes session is your quality firewall.

This requires someone whose judgment defines ‚Äúgood.‚Äù In theatre, it‚Äôs the coach or the artistic director. In AI products, it‚Äôs often the designer or a domain expert who deeply understands the audience‚Äôs context. If you‚Äôre designing AI products, you may already be this person. You just haven‚Äôt formalized the role¬†yet.

You‚Äôre not testing fixed paths. You‚Äôre not measuring funnels. You‚Äôre assessing behavior patterns across thousands of sessions.

The improv coach watches sessions, takes notes,¬†adjusts.

And the performances improve.

Neural OS gap: No state management, no review, no behavioral boundaries. No rules at¬†all.

Real AI products embody this infrastructure today‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsome elegantly, some clumsily. Let‚Äôs look at how different teams have built their¬†stages.

What this looks like in¬†practice

Claude Artifacts

(Anthropic‚Äôs split-screen AI tool for generating apps and¬†content)

The stage layout separates conversation from creation‚Ää‚Äî‚Äächat on the left, artifact on the right. Props are minimal but explicit: artifact types (code, document, diagram, React component), action buttons for copy and download, version controls. The rules govern behavior without scripting outputs: when to create versus update, how to handle corrections, what belongs in an artifact versus in the chat. The AI decides what to write and build; the rules constrain how it presents the work. The stage is a steady canvas that survives the conversation‚Äôs chaos.

Woebot

(mental health AI¬†service)

In high-stakes environments like mental health, the AI does more script-reading than usual. With Woebot, the rules are categorical: users never interact directly with an LLM. Everything Woebot says is written by clinical writers and conversational designers. In this theatre, improvisation is minimized and conservative. AI handles only intent classification‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääparsing what users mean so the system can select the right human-authored response. A ‚ÄúConcerning Language Detection‚Äù algorithm flags crisis signals before routing the conversation.

The design team conducts table reads‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa practice borrowed from theatre, film, and TV professionals‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhere conversations are read aloud, evaluated and revised to ensure they feel empathetic and¬†natural.

Props constrain the interaction: quick-reply buttons with predefined options, emoji mood selectors, structured therapy lesson modules (‚Äúchallenging thoughts,‚Äù ‚Äúsocial skills training‚Äù), an SOS crisis resource button. The stage is a branching conversational tree‚Ää‚Äî‚Äähundreds of pre-authored paths mapped out by clinical experts. When safety stakes are highest, the rules are most explicit.

Google A2UI

(open protocol for AI agents to generate native¬†UIs)

Google‚Äôs A2UI takes this to protocol level. The core insight: agents shouldn‚Äôt constantly rebuild everything from¬†scratch.

Props are the point. Each client application maintains a ‚Äúcatalog‚Äù of trusted UI components‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäCard, Button, TextField, date pickers, time selectors, custom charts‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthat agents can use as building blocks. The agent sends declarative JSON describing what UI it wants; the client decides how, via native widgets (Flutter, React, Angular, SwiftUI). Same payload, different platforms, consistent brand.

The rules are structural: no code execution, only catalog components. The client controls styling. ‚ÄúUI that‚Äôs safe like data, but expressive like code.‚Äù It‚Äôs the stage manager framework formalized as an open standard‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfrom the same company whose Neural OS demo showed us what unconstrained AI interfaces look¬†like.

The notes session in¬†practice

Improv‚Äôs post-show ‚Äúnotes session‚Äù isn‚Äôt just metaphor‚Ää‚Äî‚Äähere‚Äôs what it looks like when UX and product professionals lead AI evaluation:

Product Talk Interview Coach

(AI coaching tool for product discovery)

Interview Coach demonstrates a product professional leading successful AI evals. Teresa Torres‚Äô process: manually annotate AI outputs, identify failure patterns (like ‚Äúcoach presents leading questions‚Äù), write both code assertions and LLM-as-judge evals, then compare automated scores to human¬†labels.

Her insights cut to the heart of teamwork in the AI era: ‚ÄúNo engineer without my expertise is coming up with this really simple code assertion eval‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm able to generate that because I‚Äôve seen general questions over and over again and I‚Äôm confident that language captures them‚Ä¶. We really have to cross-functionally collaborate closer than we ever have‚Ä¶ your product manager or designer are probably going to be involved in prompt design or even eval¬†design.‚Äù

Microsoft Sales¬†Agent

(AI-generated sales outreach)

UX researchers at Microsoft conducted foundational research with sellers and buyers to define ‚Äúexperience-driven pillars of quality‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääpersonalization, tone, brevity, clear calls to action. These became evaluation criteria that simultaneously direct the AI‚Äôs generation, provide scoring rubrics for LLM judges, and frame survey questions for human evaluators.

Researcher Pooja Dhaka explains: ‚ÄúUX research anchors scoring to human judgment and context, not just compliance with benchmarks.‚Äù

The standing¬†ovation

Neural OS showed possibility, but it collapsed into chaos. A2UI, Claude Artifacts, and Woebot‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand the industry leaders united in the new Agentic AI Foundation‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääshow what happens when you design the infrastructure for¬†success.

The difference isn‚Äôt the technology‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs the¬†design.

The next¬†stage

The stakes are rising. Jensen Huang, Fei-Fei Li, and Yann LeCun are betting the new era will be defined by physical AI‚Ää‚Äî‚Äärobots and agents inhabiting physical¬†space.

When that happens, the metaphor becomes literal. When the stage is a kitchen and the props are knives, ‚Äúgraceful failure‚Äù isn‚Äôt a UX nicety‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs safety-critical. The framework holds. The margin for error¬†shrinks.

Someone must design the theatre. Someone must choose the props. Someone must lay out the rules, watch the performances, coach the cast, refine the production. Someone must make the judgment calls that algorithms can‚Äôt.

Stop being the playwright. Start being the stage¬†manager.
